newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: Slovak shares quiet, SAX dips 1.46 pts TO 201.55.
newsitem.headline: Slovak shares quiet, SAX dips 1.46 pts TO 201.55.

text.p: Leading Slovak shares closed mostly down in listless trading on the Bratislava Stock Exchange (BSE) on Wednesday, pulling the SAX index 1.46 points lower to 201.55 points.
Some brokers said market liquidity might be expected to lower gradually, with increasing number of issues having explicit majority owners.
"Only a few owners currently place their shares on the market," Patrik Granec of Slovenska Sporitelna said. "I hope the focus will slowly move to the bond market, as there are more new issues there."
Only 828 listed shares were traded on the BSE's floor. Trading with blue chips was dominated by steel maker VSZ, which closed down 16 crowns at 630, on a volume of 100 shares.
The heaviest issues, oil refinery Slovnaft and oil and gas storage firm Nafta, did not trade on Wednesday.

"Slovnaft has a strong position on the market, as it dominates also the country's petrol distribution network," Granec said, adding: "But I think it should perform the way which VSZ does; more expansion is needed to break a silence around this issue."
Granec said several direct sales were made through the bourse by the country's privatisation agency, the NPF, but brokers were unimpressed by these trades.
"Although quite large stakes were traded, I found these companies unimportant to the market," he added.

Overall volume increased to 389,956 shares, from 191,000 shares traded on Tuesday, while turnover rose to 179.2 million crowns, from 168.09 million. -- Peter Javurek, Bratislava Newsroom, 42-7-563-3687
